messages.message: @Kaustubh (KD) yes the current method searches for the extracted tokens. we dont have a great way to identify the "target areas", we have to rely on the LLM to give us a line number and try to search for the tokens there. i think @jordy.vlan ibhack project is experimenting with some better ways to localise for provenance tracking.
that was my fear based on how it's performing... this discredits our provenance feature quite significantly
@Clemens would it be helpful to brainstorm with the team on what our expectations are for provenance / what's feasible? I want to make sure we understand your feedback and align on next steps.
the feedback is quite simple... if our provenance feature finds random strings in the doc that match the answer, it's not very credible
I've actually noticed this before but in this case it's particularly obvious because the answer is just a single character
and even though the answer is correct, the provenance just picks another random occurrence of that character
what if we transformed all text and gave each word/token a hash/fingerprint ID?

Yeah in my opinion, have wrong provenance is worse than having no provenance in cases like this. It significantly reduces confidence on the overall solution.

@jordy.vlan curious to see what comes out of the hackathon to assess further. However, lets sync next week on next steps here @lydia
